content: A carbon capture and sequestration/storage (CCS) system is designed to remove CO<sub>2</sub> at the source of emission, such as a coal or natural gas plant, or from the environment. The CO<sub>2</sub> can be stored in a sealed underground chamber or used for another purpose. Currently about 40 million tons of CO<sub>2</sub> are captured each year, about 0.1% of total emissions [ccs_institute].
For industrial heat and process emissions from major commodities, CCS may be the only economically viable tool to reduce emissions by more than 30% [ccs2014].

[dac] estimate the cost from direct air capture. The IPCC [ipcc_emissions] estimates the cost from bioenergy and carbon capture and sequestration (BECCS).

Seawater may also be a promising venue for extracting carbon dioxide [willauer], though reliable potential costs estimates are limited. Recent analysis suggests that the CO<sub>2</sub> abatement cost of synthetic diesel from seawater may range from $373 to $717 per ton [eisaman].

name: Sources of carbon
content: While industrial sources of carbon tend to be cheaper than diffuse sources such as direct air capture, only limited amounts of them are available, and fossil fuel-based sources in particular will hopefully be phased out eventually. name: Usage and Storage
content: Most captured CO<sub>2</sub> today is used for enhanced oil recovery, with most of the remainder stored geologically.
A barrel of oil releases about 500 kg of CO<sub>2</sub>, and if CO<sub>2</sub> enhanced oil recovery is used, about 300-600 kg CO<sub>2</sub> are injected into the well [co2eor].

Potential future uses of captured CO2 include methanol, hydrocarbons, methane, mineralization into building materials, working fluids for coal and geothermal power plants, fertilizing plant growth in greenhouses [co2_greenhouse], feedstock for the chemical industry, and several niche industrial uses [iea_ccs][ccs_survey].

If CO<sub>2</sub> is captured from fossil fuels or cement, and then used to produce synthetic fuels, the overall process may have lower emissions than the conventional alternative, but it is not a true low-carbon process. Rather, in this scenario, each molecule of CO<sub>2</sub> is emitted over two processes rather than one.
